p: In homeopathy, T. occidentalis is used in the treatment of cancer, but its mechanism of action is not known. Torres et al. (2016) studied the effect of α/β-thujone on glioblastoma, using in vitro and in vivo models. They have observed that α/β-thujone has the ability to diminish cell viability and has antiproliferative, proapoptotic, and antiangiogenic properties in vitro. In in vivo studies, α/β-thujone has been reported to induce regression of neoplasia and inhibited angiogenic markers of VEGF, Ang-4, and CD31 inhibitors in the tumor [ 42]. The antitumoral effect of the extract obtained from thuja leaves has been evaluated on numerous cancer cell lines [ 41, 44, 63, 84].
